posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

>>72021941
>your type
INFP
>What causes you to feel under pressure?
There are a few things that can cause me to feel under pressure. For one, I know that I have a lot of expectations placed upon me to be perfect. This can feel very overwhelming at times and make me feel like I'm not good enough. I also feel pressured by society to be a certain type of person. This can be very stressful for me as I often feel like I'm not living up to what people expect from me. Since I'm an introvert I feel like I need to force myself to be more outgoing and social in order to meet people's expectations of me.
>How do you cope with pressure?
That's a tough question. I think the most important thing is to remember that I can only do my best and that it's okay to make mistakes. When I feel like I'm under too much pressure, I usually try to take a step back and focus on what's important to me. I also try to let myself feel whatever I'm feeling and not push it away. Sometimes it helps to talk to someone about what I'm going through, or just to take some time for myself. Sometimes I like to take a bath or go for a walk or spend time with a friend who makes me feel calm.
>Your favorite candle scent
I love the scent of flowers. The smell of them relaxes me and makes me feel at peace. They also make me feel more energetic. So, when I'm having a bad day, I'll light a flower scented candle so I can feel better

>>71994310
Took a whole benzedrex inhaler cotton (no, i didn't eat it, yes, i extracted it) and masturbated for 5 hours. It's weird how masturbation on stimulants is an activity that is very enjoyable and not enjoyable at the same time.

The whole time you're aware that you're kind of wasting time on what amounts to a physical pleasure farm, that the activity is pointless, that you'd make much better use of the high by doing something else that is actually productive.

But it just drags you along and along and along and you don't want to stop. That's the main thing with stimulants, I think-- you don't want to stop what you're doing because you're constantly being 'stimulated', it draws you in, and makes it impossible to get bored. It isn't some overwhelming euphoria or rush, just that reward button in your brain being held-down, every good sensation multiplied by some factor.

That being said, physically, orgasm on a stimulant drug is very weird. It IS very intense and overwhelming on a physical level, but it isn't the overwhelming euphoria you'd imagine. Just one drawn out nervous system spaz-out, makes you feel electric in a strange way.

>.>2. Pena-Marin and Bhargave make heavy use of a research method known as "meta-analysis", that is, examination of data from multiple independent studies of relevance. The citation of priorly published research supports the thesis of Pena-Marin and Bhargave without the need to entirely conduct their own research from the ground up. The implications of the studies used by Pena-Marin and Bhargave tend to point towards a general idea that the symbolic association of a "rounded" number (such as 20, instead of 19.79) causes a viewer to store an association with such a number in their semantical memory. The implication here is that aesthetic appearances, even those of numbers, have an effect on the mind of the consumer.
What one can draw from these conclusions, in a business/marketing setting, is the pricing of items, along with nutritional content, volume, etc. can be subtly and deliberately labeled in such a way to entice consumers into purchasing it. For example, "Monster Energy Zero" energy drinks are labeled as having "zero sugar". The name, "Zero" also seems definite in its statement that it is null of any "unhealthy" ingredients. Of course, the fine print is that a can of Monster Energy Zero is in fact, 10 calories. Continuing with the theme of caffeine (and the research paper), many caffeinated energy drinks use rounded numbers to list the milligrams of caffeine per can: 130mg, 150mg, 200mg, etc. A rounded number, such as one ending in zero, has some evidence to show influence on how long the effects of the caffeine will last

>>72001198
>Would it be dumb to do it in this setting?
depends on your history with set and setting. do you like to trip in public? MDA is a full blown psychedelic unlike MDMA, albeit the headspace is incredibly light comparatively to something like LSD or mushrooms. its obviously much more like MDMA than either of those drugs, but it is also dose dependent for how trippy it gets, in my personal experience anything above 150mg of MDA would be a little too psychedelic to be in public on, but something like 80-120mg would be good for clubbing. the only stipulation is if you don't know how sensitive you are going to be to MDA, i would try it first in a controlled setting to gauge how much you want to take. you might need much more than me, i'm pretty sensitive to psychs. also my experience with dose is skewed though, cause i've only ever taken MDA while also smoking stupid amounts of weed so keep that in mind if you are or aren't smoking any weed. another note about dose, i was taking MDA made from sassafras, not any pure chemical acetone washed clear crystals or whatever. drink a small amount of alcohol to kill the psychedelia while keeping the empathogenic effects works good for me, keep it in mind if you are open to drinking while on it.
>Is it like MDMA but longer?
it didn't last any longer than regular MDMA for me, might have been shorter even.

taking MDA there sounds fun. go for it imo

>>71995197
I did 30mg Adderall and 3.5g of I think golden teacher, and the 2 definitely synergize. I was planning on studying for my Networking class taking the adderall first, but I usually get sick after taking adderall, so I thought taking the mushrooms would ease my nerves and let me drink water because not drinking enough water is usually what gets me sick. As soon as the mushrooms kicked in I was not in the same space it's almost as if my entire room turned into a painting things were much thicker and they were running like a river, I felt as though my skin itself were cold and thick just like I paint and looking in the mirror felt as I had been framed like a painting. I have done acid plenty of time, but mushrooms have this completely different trip. I don't know if it was due to the adderall, but my mushroom trip was very relaxing I felt as though I was in control the entire time where as with acid it feels like an overwhelming roller coaster ride that never ends and you're at the mercy of. There is also an intense body element to the trip I felt very warm inside my body almost as if I was fire it was very strange, but strangely nostalgic and comforting. I just had an overwhelming sense of euphoria, but not artificial like MDMA where you know it's going to end when the drug ends, but truly I felt at peace on this trip. My most intense part of the trip was when I was just laying in my bed and I closed my eyes and I began to feel as if I was a log cabin, or all things in my mind I can associate with a log cabin where felt in my body. I felt like I was the fire in the fireplace, the wood of the structure, the smoke stack coming from the chimney.

This combination is top tier definitely need to try again, and I just want to wish you well on your trip as well.

P.S. Don't masturbate it's underwhelming and you'd be better off enjoying different aspects of the trip.

Some external geometry, maybe some light closed eye visuals (probably 2D geometry, the more interesting CEVs tend to only appear on higher doses for me), some morphing and breathing. Weird thoughts, but no serious cognitive impairment.
Your come-up should be pretty smooth at such a low dose, it can be pretty rough on higher doses.
Do keep in mind that the whole experience will probably still last 6-8 hours.

Beyond that, a lot of it varies from person to person.

Have fun!

Other tips, sorry if you're already aware:

Get biotene mouthwash to protect your teeth if you continue to use (along with daily brushing ofc)

Hydration and electrolytes Pedialyte or coconut water is the best, sports drinks are better than nothing. Water obviously and lots of it but electrolytes are equally important

Consume protein, carbs and fats. Your brain needs carbohydrates to help produce more dopamine if you've been abusing drugs, so no keto. A protein shake with coconut water some berries, a banana, and a tablespoon or two of raw oatmeal (blend well) will literally make a night and day difference in hiw you feel.

Sleep, avoid melatonin. Benzos work but that another can of worms and should only be used in rare emergencies (I say this as someone pgysically addicted to rc benzos)
Magnesium l threonate is actually the best form of magnesium for the brain and will help you sleep, but magnesium glycinate is the best for stiff muscles, a combo might work nice.

Supplements can only do so much. Eventually your gonna have to stop or keep for rare occasions. Hate to break it to you. Cold showers cardio and sun exposure all help withdrawal symptoms and help your brains dopamine levels recover quickly btw.

Most people don't even engage in conversation in that scenario. They just ignore strangers and stick with whoever they're familiar with by default. At least, that's how it works where I'm from.

Businesses *want* the least amount of friction for the lowest functioning members so they can get their money.

The hard part is being able to take these punches in the first place, especially if you're alone. And unfortunately, making friends and being likeable is a lot more nuanced than learning how to approach new stores.

Medieval chivalry had very little do to with combat, it was something of an informal code of conduct regarding how a man, particularly a warrior, should behave with respect to God, the Church, his lord, his community, and the weaker members of society, particularly, women, children, and the elderly. When it came to battle, it boiled down to, don't be a pussy or a mindless butcher. Unless you're killing enemies of God and Church, in which case, butcher away. The courtly love simp shit was part of medieval popular literature, and annoyingly it's what "chivalry" came to mean as the west became gynocentric, with the ideal losing much of its meaning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Third time making it but I had sheesh tawook last night, arab chicken skewers. Still have toum, an arab mayonnaise using garlic and lemon instead of eggs. And hummus leftover from the other night but most people know what that is, one bean dip made of garbanzo beans, garlic, lemon, and sesame seed paste. Pita was bought from a med bakery that gets bread shipped in from a state 10 hours away.
Maybe I'm thinking mexican because of all the cumin but it would be better spicy. I added cayenne to the marinade and again on the skewers just before grilling this try but there was still no heat. Probably have to coat it in the stuff since I killed my capsaicin receptors somehow. Or maybe use something spicy in the marinade but cayenne is all I can usually find. The hummus was under salted somehow despite nervously following the recipe. Experience suggests most recipes either over salt or don't tell the brand of salt or use volumetric measurements of ultra light feather salt. Garlic could stand to be a little more prominent too, but I'm quite pleased with the first try of making hummus. It made a lot and the texture is better than the store bought stuff, price is actually a bit cheaper than buying store bought too.
As a general rule I triple garlic when looking at recipes but seeing as the toum called for a heaping cup of peeled garlic to three cups of oil I thought I'd try it mostly as written. For the first time ever it was something that actually tasted like garlic using just the suggested amounts, so I don't plan to alter it further. Only change I made was not adding the water because that sounded fucking dumb.
https://feelgoodfoodie.net/recipe/shish-tawook/
https://www.seriouseats.com/traditional-toum
https://www.seriouseats.com/israeli-style-extra-smooth-hummus-recipe
Picrel is the pita I bought. Made in Michigan, where the woman who broke my heart used to live.
It's a huge departure from how I usually cook but it's fun.

One made me look at a laser point in the wall that moved from side to side, then close my eyes and think about something she asked. Doing that for like half an hour or more. I think the theory behind it is that the point moving side to side simulates the how your eyes move when you are sleeping in the REM zone and there the brain consolidates memory or something like that. So it is like some kind of hypnosis trying to substitute some thoughts for others. At first I was shocked that was what my parents were paying 50 bucks/hour for and also trying to not laugh because it looked like some fake hypnosis bullshit.

But there isn't much more about psychologists, they ask you what is your problem, then about your life, relationship with your parents, then they give you some psychological explanation of what happens to you and finally they try different therapies or drugs to see if something helps you. A few beginner suggestions are:

TENS 2000/3000/7000
Ultima 5 TENS
Dungeon Labs - Coyote
E-Stim Systems - Electropebble
Erostek - ET-232
The latter two options provide the most in terms of usability as you progress from just starting to experimenting with different settings and electrode configurations. The TENS units will have the least amount of power available, and have the most "stingy" output sensation of them all. The ET-323 is reported as the least stingy, though your experience and preference may vary. Ultimately the TENS units accomplish the task of allowing you to feel EStim for very cheap, but the EStim itself is not the best quality of likely to let you orgasm or feel intense pleasure. The Dungeon Labs Coyote is likely your best "bang for the buck" but it seems to be cheaply made in the experience of some users.

Electrode Basics
To stimulate nerves each channel requires at least two electrodes, allowing the electricity to flow in, through, and out of the body.

TENS pads (smaller quantities of 2x2 TENS pads with pin connectors can be found online) are great for beginners. Most TENS pads have a self-adhesive conductive gel that sticks well to smooth skin (it is advisable to wait a day after hair removal before using TENS pads with EStim; this allows any irritation to heal). To improve adhesion, clean skin with a non-oily astringent like alcohol or witch hazel applied with pre-moistened wipes, cotton ball, sponge makeup pads or microfiber cloth (do not use paper products as leftover particles impair adhesion).

you're actually retarded and you fundamentally misunderstand the hierarchy of needs. The point of the hierarchy, as established by Abraham Maslow, isn't about "what will I literally die without" it's a theory of psychology that has to do with "what does the brain prioritize, in order of importance?". That's the whole point. Otherwise, this pyramid would be pointless, nobody needs to be told that food is necessary for survival. The brain operates such that food, air, water, shelter and the like are of the utmost priority, and included in that category is sex. The brain considers sex to be a primary motivating factor
